Description: Traditional priority-based scheduling adapted for quantum tasks. Higher priority given to tasks with shorter coherence times.
Advantages: Simple to implement; Well-understood from classical RTOS; Fast scheduling decisions
Disadvantages: May lead to starvation; Does not guarantee deadlines; Priority inversion issues
Use Case / Application: Short quantum circuits with varying urgency levels

Description: EDF (Earliest Deadline First) adapted for quantum computing. Deadlines set based on decoherence limits.
Advantages: Optimal for single processor; Guarantees deadlines if feasible; Better utilization
Disadvantages: Complex feasibility analysis; Overhead in deadline computation; May waste quantum resources
Use Case / Application: Hard real-time quantum applications with strict timing requirements

Description: Quantum circuits divided into smaller schedulable units with intermediate measurements.
Advantages: Allows context switching; Better resource sharing; Flexible scheduling
Disadvantages: State preservation overhead; Increased decoherence risk; Complex partitioning decisions
Use Case / Application: Long quantum algorithms that exceed coherence time

Description: Co-schedules classical and quantum resources considering communication delays.
Advantages: Optimizes overall system; Reduces idle time; Communication-aware
Disadvantages: High complexity; Requires coordination; Difficult to predict execution time
Use Case / Application: Variational quantum algorithms (VQE, QAOA) with classical-quantum loops

Description: Machine learning-based approaches that learn from hardware characteristics and adapt online.
Advantages: Adapts to hardware; Learns optimal strategies; Can handle variability
Disadvantages: Requires training data; Overhead in prediction; May not work for new workloads
Use Case / Application: Complex quantum systems with repeating workload patterns

Description: Fixed-priority scheduling based on task periodicity. Shorter period = higher priority.
Advantages: Predictable behavior; Static analysis possible; Well-studied bounds
Disadvantages: Requires periodic tasks; May have low utilization; Limited to specific task models

Description: Specialized scheduling for quantum annealing systems. Focus on parameter scheduling.
Advantages: Optimized for annealing; Considers energy landscape; Hardware-specific
Disadvantages: Limited to annealing hardware; Not general-purpose; Narrow application
Use Case / Application: Quantum optimization problems on D-Wave systems
